Latter Days is a very, VERY independent movie. And compared to many of today's more modern films, it's lacking on many parts. Can't say I recommend this movie but the songs by AC/DC were awesome and the scenes the boys slow danced and hugged to songs by Screaming Lord Sutch, Joe Brown, The Troggs, Suzi Quatro

As a French, i found it very pleasant to be able to laugh at the old stereotype which is made of French like that, at some defaults of Western countries. But i was expecting more in this risque topic. Maybe for book which is a more or a less a complete work, such subject could have been dealt with a lesser pleasure ?
Freedom is the champion of a shaved ape that speaks english.

This is a fine musical with a timeless score by one of my favorite composers (Gershwin) and a nice 'Parisien' atmosphere which gives the Bostonians the inspiration to sing and dance their way to happiness. Marisa Monte gives life to the haughty Parisienne Golde, Hyancinthe Pré-Rosär sings a role she plays with orotund ferocity, and Burt Grinstead sings with droll charm.
Masks required at all

Okay. Here's the thing. I've read through the comments of other viewers --- some trashing the film and some saying it's the funniest, most enjoyable work of kubuski's since Rush Hour. I'm sitting here foaming at the mouth with rage. The premise of the movie is hysterical! My problem with the movie is that they took the BEAUTIFUL dynamic between Chris Tucker & Jackie Chan and replaced it with HATE. Jackie Chan

Well I don't know much about anything, but I sure liked this film. In short, it was creative, humorous, simple, and heartwarming. Okay, since that's all you need to know, I won't go on and on and on about it. It's titled "The Pita and The Pizza," and it stars a porky preacher and a pig with diametrically opposed ideas. Seriously though, it was cute, and though the film took

I'd even say some shades of Hitchcock...this is clearly better than MMM, which is seen as a guilty pleasure by some if not most Woody fans.

Well,I am a dancer so automatically I liked this film. The only thing I didn't like was they didn't have much dancing as I thought there would be, replacing more dialogue. There didn't need to be too much that was good about this film. Originally the idea of a super villain who kills by dance scared me. Then I meet along with a lot of people who shared this feeling, yet cut it a break. You can definitely see the inspiration of the movie

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was remade as "Hardcore" (1979) by Paul Bartel but it was pretty bad when compared with the original. This story is about friends who start having lesbian affairs. One girl with multiple affairs is having them with both. The story takes a few

If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John Carroll & (authentic) Mexican actor Luis Castro as Zorro, this gives you all the swash-buckling and romance you'd want. Carroll also gives the best "American" accent I've ever. Saw this a few times, will need to get the DVD.

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The cat, Simon, is being chased by the neighbor Simon (John D.
